subject: Climate & Environment
title: The Great London Smog
description: A micro-lesson that makes The Great London Smog usable.

hook.text: In December 1952, a thick yellow fog settled over London and refused to leave for five days.

buildup.text: Cold weather trapped coal smoke at ground level. Visibility dropped to near zero.

discovery.text: Hospitals overflowed. Undertakers ran out of coffins. An estimated 12,000 people died.

twist.text: The government initially blamed influenza. It took years to admit coal smoke was the killer.

climax.text: The disaster led to the Clean Air Act of 1956 â€” the world's first major air quality law.

punchline.text: London's deadliest disaster wasn't a bomb. It was the air.

quiz.question: How many people died in the 1952 Great London Smog?
